answer2: The script file must be found in the $PATH.
answer3: The script file must have the executable permission bit set.
answer4: The script must begin with a shebang-line (#!) that points to the correct interpreter.
answer5: The file system on which the script resides must be mounted with the option scripts.

answer5: Create a .nologin file in the user's home directory.

answer2: Add the specific user to [deny] section in the /etc/atd.conf file.
answer3: Add the specific user to /etc/at.deny file.
answer4: Add the specific user to nojobs group.

question: What is true about the ntpdate command?
answer1: It is the primary management command for the NTP time server.
answer2: It updates the local system's date (i.e. day, month and year) but not the time (i.e. hours, minutes, seconds).
answer3: It queries one or more NTP time servers and adjusts the system time accordingly.
answer4: It sends the local system time to one or many remote NTP time servers for redistribution.
answer5: It can be used by any user to set the user clock independently of the system clock.

answer2: It would be directly transmitted on the device eth0.
answer3: It would be passed to the default router 255.255.255.0 on eth0.

answer5: It would be passed to the router 192.168.1.1 on eth0.
